'Guanosine' is a purine nucleoside comprising guanine attached to a ribose
(ribofuranose) ring via a Î²-N 9-glycosidic bond. Guanosine can be
phosphorylated to become guanosine monophosphate (GMP), cyclic guanosine
monophosphate (cGMP), guanosine diphosphate (GDP), and guanosine triphosphate
(GTP). These forms play important roles in various biochemical processes such as
synthesis of nucleic acids and proteins, photosynthesis, muscle contraction and
intracellular signal transduction (cGMP). When guanine is attached by its N9
nitrogen to the C1 carbon of a deoxyribose ring it is known as deoxyguanosine.

The antiviral drug aciclovir, often used in herpes treatment, is structurally
similar to guanosine.

Guanosine is required for an RNA splicing reaction in mRNA, when a "self-
splicing" intron removes itself from the mRNA message by cutting at both ends,
re-ligating, and leaving just the exons on either side to be translated into
protein. [http://blogs.scienceforums.net/ecoli/files/2008/04/introns.jpg
Splicing (JPG)]
